metadata.title: Driver Rehabilitation
description: Driver rehabilitation programs include driving skills assessment, education, skills training, and instruction in the use of adaptive equipment and compensatory techniquesrelated to driving(9)
Driver rehabilitation typically includes an off-road  assessment of performance components of driving and an on-road  assessment (usually in a car with dual controls)(1)

Driver rehabilitation programs can be divided into three levels: basic, low-tech,  and high-tech(10) –Basic programs provide evaluation, training, and education; designed for persons who can independently transfer into/out of a car and can use standard driving controls; may include adaptive aids that do not affect the operation of standard vehicle controls (e.g., seat cushion or additional mirrors); may also include transportation planning –Low-tech  programs provide comprehensive evaluation, training, and education and may involve the use of adaptive driving aids for primary and secondary vehicle controls; adaptations of primary controls are typically at the mechanical level (e.g., pedal extensions or gas/brake hand controls); adaptations for secondary controls may include wireless or remote access (e.g.,remote horn or wiper controls); transfers, seating, and positioning in standard driver’s seat are addressed –High-tech  programs include all aspects of the basic and low-tech  programs, but also involve the use of high-tech adaptive equipment options to operate vehicle controls (e.g., powered gas/brake system, joystick control, powered transmission shifters, and touch pads or switch arrays for electronics); also include structural modifications needed for transferring into/out of a vehicle (e.g., transfer seat base, ramps, lifts)
Driver rehabilitation typically is conducted by occupational therapists (OTs) who have completed postgraduate training in driver assessment and rehabilitation(1)
indications: Health/impairment issues that may affect driving ability(1) –Impaired upper limb movement –Impaired or absent lower limb movement –Reduced visual acuity, visual-perceptual,  or cognitive abilities –Reduced problem-solving  abilities

Driver assessments commonly are provided for(1) –Young adults with congenital or acquired impairments –Individuals who are recovering from/adapting to physical, neurological, or psychosocial conditions -Spinal cord injury (SCI), traumatic brain injury (TBI), and cerebrovascular accident (CV A) often result in the need for driver rehabilitation(9)  –Individuals with a degenerative chronic illness –Older individuals living in the community who have decreased abilities due to the aging process

Health conditions that have been identified with an increase in motor vehicle accidents(1) –Dementia –Epilepsy –Multiple sclerosis –Sleep apnea –Alcohol abuse –Cataracts –Arthritis –Heart disease –Hypertension –Orthopedic conditions –Visual/hearing impairment –Psychiatric disorders
reimbursement: Workers’ compensation and vocational rehabilitation programs may pay for driver assessment, driver rehabilitation, and vehicle modifications
Private insurance, Medicare, and Medicaid do not reimburse driver evaluations Indications for Driver Rehabilitation
contraindications precautions to test: Precautions and contraindications are specific to the related diagnosis. As always, appropriate caution should be used when evaluating patients presenting with any visual-perceptive, cognitive, and/or motor impairments from injury or illness

contraindications precautions to examina: Precautions and contraindications are specific to the related diagnosis. As always, appropriate caution should be used when evaluating patients presenting with any visual-perceptive, cognitive, and/or motor impairments from injury or illness

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document start of underlying diagnosis, progression of illness/injury, rehabilitation course, and any complications or comorbid injuries

course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Note any medication that can make it unsafe to operate a vehicle
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Document diagnostic tests/lab work completed for the patient
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document use of supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilator, etc. Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__/No__  -If Yes, describe

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease,psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders (e.g., neck or upper extremity dysfunction), ocular/visual and disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing Social/occupational history  (1)Document what the patient hopes to accomplish with therapy and in generalDoes the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?Document if the patient’s occupation involves drivingDoes the patient require use of a wheelchair, frontwheel  walker, single-point  cane for mobility?Document environmental factors such as traffic, highway or city or rural driving, night versus daytime driving, road conditions.(3) Ask where patient will drive, how often, when patient wants to drive, and if other persons will be present when patient drives

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) A comprehensive driving evaluation (CDE) includes off-road  and on-road  assessment–includes detailed history, driving habits, driving history, and clinical tests to assess vision, motor skills, and cognitive and sensory performance.(1)Also, determine the status of the patient’s license and the availability of a suitable vehicle to drive(9)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess use of assistive and adaptive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess dynamic and static sitting balance –Assess static and dynamic standing balance
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess physical endurance for driving (e.g., how long can the patient sit before he or she becomes fatigued?) •Ergonomics/body mechanics
Assess body mechanics with functional transfers, standing, and sitting
Note if patient requires any special equipment (seat cushions, lumbar back brace) when operating a vehicle •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.)
Assess functional mobility, including use of assistive devices; the Functional Independence Measure (FIM) can be used as an objective measurement to assess mobility
Assess ability to get in/out of vehicle
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Screen for gait dysfunction or impaired wheelchair mobility. Refer to physical therapy as appropriate –Determine if patient uses a cane or walker for mobility Motor function  (motor control/tone/learning) –Assess upper and lower extremity coordination –Assess for abnormal tone
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle testing of upper and lower extremities. Note any weakness in strength and compare both sides Perception  (e.g., visual fields, spatial relations) acuity, eye movement, eye coordination, visual fields, contrast sensitivity(1) –Perceptual assessments -Trail Making Test (TMT)(1) -A pencil and paper test that has high predictive validity, yet is limited to those individuals who are able to read and comprehend the English alphabet -Useful Field of View (UFOV)(1) -Motor Free Visual Perception Test (MVPT)(1) -Rivermead Perceptual Assessment Battery (RPAB)(1)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess posture for sitting and standing activities
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess passive and active ROM and flexibility in upper and lower extremities –Assess cervical neck rotation ROM and thoracic ROM
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Self-care/activities  of daily living –The Barthel Index can be used for objective measurement for patients with neurological or musculoskeletal disorders –ADLs have demonstrated a strong, positive correlation to driving ability in patients with morbidities (i.e., post stroke)(4)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testingsuperficial sensation, proprioception, kinesthesia(1)note whether patient requires hearing aids
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –SAFEDRIVE – screening tool to identify the need for driver assessment. The following areas are to be reviewed and may(1) -Safety record and history of accidents -Attention deficits and skills -Family report of driving-related  problems -Ethanol use/history of alcohol use -Drug/medication use -Reaction time limitations -Intellectual impairment -Vision-related  problems -Executive cognition limitations/concerns –Assessments for predicting on-road  driving performance -Stroke Driver Screening Assessment(2) -Cognitive Behavioral Driver’s Inventory (CBDI) -Visual Recognition Slide Test (VRST) -Assesses recall and visual scanning -Displays images to patients for 3 seconds, patients then report details about the position and direction of travel of each pedestrian and vehicle in each image. It also includes an on-road driving assessment -Assessment of Driving-Related  Skills (ADReS) -Components of this assessment include Snellen E Chart for visual acuity, Visual Fields by Confrontation Testing, Trail-Making  Test (Part B), Clock Drawing Test, Rapid Pace Walk Test, Range of Motion assessment, Manual Test of Motor Strength(11) -Occupational Therapy – Driver Off Road Assessment (OT-DORA)  Battery -Driving Behavior Questionnaire -DriveABLE Competence Screen -The DriveABLE assessment is a useful tool for predicting the driving ability of patients post stroke related to cognitive function(6)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition  (including memory, problem solving) –Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE)(1) –Rivermead Behavioral Memory Test (RBMT)(1) –Test of Everyday Attention (TEA)(1) –Digit Substitution Test, part of Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale(1)

other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for procedure Visual perceptual, cognitive, and motor impairments from injury, illness, or age-related  changes that may impact driving performance(9) SCI, TBI, CV A, and arthritis are diagnoses often resulting in the need for driver rehabilitation(9)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines –Physical therapy –Speech therapy –Ophthalmology/neuro-optometry  (vision therapy) –Psychology –Audiology –Social work
other considerations: Other considerations –The OT should perform an off-road  evaluation and collaborate with a driving school instructor. After an on-road  test, the OT and driving school instructor should discuss the outcome and provide any necessary recommendations(1) –Throughout the evaluation, the OT should pay close attention to the underlying performance skills required for driving in order to determine appropriate interventions to support skill remediation as needed(9) –Individualized on-road  training lessons and restricted licensing can support eventual return to driving for patients who fail an initial driving assessment(13) -Based on a study in which researchers assessed the goals, processes, and efficacy of on-road  training lessons for persons with mild to severe TBI -Study included 340 participants; all participants completed a standard occupational therapy driver assessment which included an off-road  and on-road assessment -Participants who failed the initial assessment (94 total) were provided with further on-road  training with goals focusing on the errors/difficulties encountered during the initial assessment; goals included compensatory strategies for cognitive difficulties (e.g., attention, memory, processing speed, planning, navigation), adaptive equipment training and/or compensatory strategies for physical impairments, visual strategies to improve field loss or other visual difficulties, strengthening of prior skills (e.g., road law knowledge, adapting to driving environment, and increasing general driving experience), and management of psychological issues (e.g., anxiety, poor confidence) -An average of seven on-road  lessons were provided; reassessments were then completed to determine readiness to drive -After receiving on-road  training, 42 participants successfully returned to driving with an unrestricted license and 45 returned to driving with a restricted license; licensing restrictions included a restricted driving area, automatic transmission only, and/or necessary adaptive equipment –Self-awareness  of driving performance may be an important component of the driver rehabilitation process(14) -Based on a study in which researchers investigated the impact of self-awareness  of driving on successful completion of a return to driving assessment among persons with TBI; the relationship between self-awareness  of driving ability and cognitive functions required for driving was also investigated -Study included 37 participants with moderate to severe TBI who were referred for a return to driving assessment and49 healthy controls -All participants completed on on-road  evaluation and were administered assessments measuring fine motor control, psychomotor speed, attentional switching, visuospatial perception, executive functioning, and mood; a driving self-awareness  measure was also completed by each participant as well as on-road evaluations completed by clinicians -24 participants with TBI passed the on-road assessment and 13 failed; results of the self-awareness  measure indicated that those who failed had significantly reduced awareness of driving ability. They tended to overestimate their performance and rate their skills higher than the clinicians; reduced awareness was associated with increased frequency of driving errors during the on-road  assessment as well as impairments with psychomotor speed, attentional switching, and visual perception  –Patients who are no longer able to drive and live alone in the community should be given interventions to address age-related  physical/mental changes as well as environmental changes(1) -Interventions should include mobility counseling(5) which focuses on problem solving, access to community resource and alternative transportation, and education on planning and scheduling transportation in advance -Planning should focus on maintaining and expanding a patient’s social network, prioritizing physical activities as needed, and learning how to ask for assistance from others –The OT should provide older adults with training on use of technological resources such as videophones, social networking, and Skype to allow older adults to keep in contact with friends and families(1) –Patients with related diagnoses (e.g., post stroke) may demonstrate marked differences in ability to drive -Patients post right hemispheric lesions are 1.7 times more likely to cross the central line while driving and 4.8 times more likely to have an accident compared to patients with left hemispheric lesions(7) –For patients with cognitive decline or related diagnosis, family and caregiver interviews are imperative for obtaining a more global assessment of driving history and ability(8) –Driver rehabilitation practices can support driving readiness and/or community mobility skills for teenagers and young adults with high-functioning  autism spectrum disorder (ASD)(16) -Based a study in which researchers implemented a “boot camp” program to facilitate improved driving knowledge and skills, examine alternative community mobility options, and implement skill-building activities to improve general safety -Study included eight participants between 15 and 19 years of age -Bootcamp program lasted 7 weeks: week one included five (7-hour)  days of training; weeks 2–7 included two (90-minute)  training sessions per week -Skill-building  activities focused on hazard identification, traffic controls and road rules, vehicle safety education, use of bus systems and planning a trip, and role-playing  scenarios -In a follow-up  survey after completing the program, two participants obtained their driver’s license, two reported increased confidence about either community mobility in general or about proceeding to enroll in a formal driver’s education program, and one reported success with consistently using the bus system at his university
treatment summary: Treatment summary –An OT driver rehabilitation assessment includes a general occupational profile, driver safety screens, and evaluation of vision, visual perception, cognition, and motor skills(9) –The off-road  driving assessment should assess for the following: insight/self-awareness,  planning/foresight, judgment, and problem-solving  ability. An on-road  assessment which takes the patient through various road conditions, traffic patterns, and settings is also completed to determine if the patient has the mental and physical skills required for safe driving(9) –OTs working in driver rehabilitation assist in determining medical fitness to drive and utilize a variety of intervention approaches to support driving readiness(15) -In a survey of OTs from three stroke rehabilitation hospitals in Canada, respondents indicated that office-based  measures are typically used to screen physical-motor  and cognitive-perceptual  abilities of patients post stroke; measures may include standardized, subjective, and/or technology-based (driving simulation) screening tools to assess driving readiness -Interventions used to improve driving readiness skills include technology-based  activities (e.g., driving simulator, iPad activities, computer games/activities), table-top  activities (e.g., visual scanning and other worksheets, driving scenario questionnaires), and physical activities (e.g., walking, throwing, and catching, path-finding/navigating  activities, activities involving car controls) –Driving simulators can be used in driver rehabilitation, either as part of the initial assessment process or for skill training(9,15) -Driving simulators provide virtual scenarios that reflect different traffic conditions and allow clinicians to observe how a patient reacts in various driving situations(9) -Researchers who studied combat veterans with multiple injuries/associated conditions who drove prior to combat and who had the potential to return to driving found that a simulator-based  occupational therapy driving intervention was more effective than standard traffic safety education in reducing driving-related  errors(12) -Study included 26 participants who were randomly assigned to either the intervention (simulator-based  training) group or the control (traffic-safety  education) group  -Intervention group participated in three 1-hour sessions of simulator training focusing on identification of driving errors, personalized strategies to reduce errors, and practice with strategy implementation; the intervention was provided by an occupational therapy driver rehabilitation specialist (OT-DRS) -The control group received3 hours of traffic-safety  education focusing on traffic knowledge, vehicle safety, accident prevention, defensive driving control, psychological factors that can impact driving, and driving under the influence of various substances; the education was based on a traffic safety curriculum and was provided by a traffic safety official and through video -Participants in both groups completed pre- and post-test  assessments focusing on visual, sensory, cognitive, and motor functioning as well as a simulator-based  assessment of driving errors (e.g., speed regulation, lane maintenance, visual scanning, gap acceptance/timing of turns, adjustment to stimuli, vehicle spacing/positioning, and signaling) -Results indicated that participants in the intervention group made fewer errors relating to speed regulation, signaling, gap acceptance, and total number of driving errors at post-test compared to the control group –OTs working in driver rehabilitation also make recommendations regarding equipment options that would best support a patient’s driving ability(9) –Examples of vehicle adaptations(10) -Steering: steering knob, palm grip, tri-pin,  joystick controls, reduced/low effort steering devices. Devices are useful for patients with CV A, multiple sclerosis, SCI, or arthritic conditions -Accelerator and brake controls: pedal extensions, left foot accelerator, gas pedal block, hand controls. Useful for patients with a CV A (right hemiplegia) or right-leg  amputees. Hand controls can be used which are attached to the accelerator and brake, allowing drivers to control the vehicle with their hands -Mirrors: to assist checking blind spots or broaden peripheral vision -Seating and positioning: cushions, swivel base seats for transfer, wheelchair securement systems -Handybar: removable grab bar for transferring in/out of the vehicle -Leg lift strap: allows patients with lower extremity weakness or pain to strap their lower extremity over the vehicle threshold to safely sit in the driver seat -Global positioning system (GPS): allows easy navigation by inputting the destination’s address into the system -Backup camera: allows patient to view the rear of the vehicle on a video screen in the front dashboard –Vision is an important aspect of driving. Retraining of ocular functioning should focus on visual exercises, improving awareness, and visual scanning –Patients with motor impairments should be encouraged to participate in a home exercise program. Strength, ROM, and flexibility are critical components to being able to safely operate a vehicle . desired outcomes and related outcome mea: Return to safely operating a vehicle–Cognitive Behavioral Driver’s Inventory (CBDI)–DriveABLE Competence Screen–Occupational Therapy – Driver Off Road Assessment (OT-DORA) Battery–Assessment of Driving-Related  Skills (ADReS)–Driving Behavior Questionnaire–Stroke Driver Screening Assessment(2)
Improved coordination, strength, ROM–Rapid alternating foot tap–Manual muscle testing–Goniometry–Rapid Pace Walk Test(11)
Improved vision and visual perceptual abilities–Snellen E Chart
